summary: Managing Your Finances in Uncertain Times
locationaddress: Online
categories: Type,Location,Audience,Workshop,Online,Faculty,Staff,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Postdocs,WorkLife,org/worklife,Wellness
description: <p>When times are uncertain, it&rsquo;s a good idea to review your finances and how you manage them. You may want to reassess your tolerance for risk, reexamine your goals and change your savings and retirement plans. This seminar discusses the foundations of a good financial plan and what adjustments you might want to make in uncertain times.</p>\n<p>Presenter: Facilitator from Humana/HRI (Columbia University&rsquo;s Employee Assistance Program)&nbsp;</p>

summary: Junior Class | Honor Pin Event with CCSC, ESC, Academic Integrity
locationaddress: Lerner Hall, 2920 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
categories: org/cc_seas_familysupport,Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Student,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Columbia College,Columbia Engineering,Core Curriculum,Juniors,Combined Plan Students,Lunch,Ceremony,Education,Engineering
description: <p>Join Columbia College and Engineering Student Councils Junior Class representatives and the Director of Academic Integrity to receive your Honor pins. These pins are a symbol of your commitment to &quot;Wear the Crown with Honor.&quot; Since your class started virtually at Columbia here is your chance to pick up your honor pin, get some free Fumo food, and experience this Columbia tradition on Lerner Ramps! Questions? Email <a href="mailto:ugrad-integrity@columbia.edu?subject=Question%20about%20Junior%20Pin%20Event" target="_blank">ugrad-integrity@columbia.edu&nbsp;</a></p>

summary: Viral Justice: Pandemics, Policing and Public Bioethics
locationaddress: Online Event
categories: org/ethics,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Online,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Social Justice,Postdocs,org/irvinginstitute,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Trainees,Grand Rounds,org/cumc,Humanities
description: <p>Join us for the first session in our Ethics Grand Rounds 2022/23 series with&nbsp;<strong>Ruha Benjamin</strong>,&nbsp;<strong>PhD,</strong>&nbsp;Professor of African American Studies at Princeton University and Founding Director of the Ida B. Wells Just Data Lab.</p>\n<p>Professor Benjamin&#39;s session is entitled:&nbsp;<strong>Viral Justice:</strong>&nbsp;<strong>Pandemics, Policing, and Public Bioethics&nbsp;</strong>and examines the topic of incarceration, policing and health justice and specifically, how incarceration in the US must be understood in terms of health and equity. The session will be moderated by&nbsp;<strong>Sandra Soo-Jin Lee</strong>,&nbsp;<strong>PhD,</strong>&nbsp;Chief of the Division of Ethics and Professor of Medical Humanities and Ethics at Columbia University and Vagelos College of Physicians and Surgeons.</p>\n<p><a href="https://columbiacuimc.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_ZGAvNYsqS9G9lLG31p3xtg" target="_blank">Register for Viral Justice here.</a></p>

summary: CANCELED--Writing about Law and Politics with Elie Mystal
locationaddress: Pulitzer Hall, 2950 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Pulitzer Hall,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Discussion,Graduate Students,Trainees,org/Journalism,Journalism
description: <p>Elie Mystal is the Justice Correspondent for The Nation, where he writes about courts, criminal justice, and politics. Trained as a lawyer, he is also the author of&nbsp;Allow Me To Retort: A Black Guy&#39;s Guide to the Constitution. He will be in conversation with Keith Gessen of the J-School&#39;s Delacorte Center for Magazine Journalism.</p>\n<p>If you would like to attend in person and are NOT part of the Columbia Journalism School community, you must RSVP:&nbsp;<a href="https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__www.eventbrite.com_e_433538765117&amp;d=DwMFaQ&amp;c=009klHSCxuh5AI1vNQzSO0KGjl4nbi2Q0M1QLJX9BeE&amp;r=dklbyzSWtZ2Rtp6axmmMysLm1nwYDL9H76xsAJuJXtk&amp;m=wbkblEkUK0zuii5fzN1WJuuhcmlQSflATk183000A_hHOgE8HXcbi8V5W5Y12JTB&amp;s=CLE8NZrm5v4iyhGqoxaU0jSc9HwMTkqW1mzFzSjbIho&amp;e=" target="_blank">https://www.eventbrite.com/e/433538765117</a></p>\n<p>QUESTIONS? Contact Keith Gessen:&nbsp;<a href="mailto:kag2174@columbia.edu" target="_blank">kag2174@columbia.edu</a></p>

summary: Film Screening & Discussion. "Tell Her" by Alexander Molochnikov
locationaddress: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Film,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Trainees,Russia,org/SIPA_HarrimanInstitute,Humanities
description: <h2>Important Note</h2>\n<p><strong>Registration required. Please note that all attendees must follow Columbia&rsquo;s&nbsp;<a href="https://covid19.columbia.edu/" target="_blank">COVID-19 Policies and Guidelines</a>. Columbia University is committed to protecting the health and safety of its community.&nbsp; To that end,&nbsp;<strong>all visiting alumni and guests</strong>&nbsp;must meet the University requirement of full vaccination status in order to attend in-person events.&nbsp; Vaccination cards may be checked upon entry to all venues.&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong></p>\n<p>Please join us for the screening of&nbsp;<em>Tell Her (2020)</em>&nbsp;and the following discussion with the film director&nbsp;<strong>Aleksander Molochnikov.</strong>&nbsp;A prominent Russian theatre and film director, Molochnikov staged several major performances at the Moscow Art Theatre as well as at the Bolshoi. He is widely known for his work on television and was a recent guest on the popular YouTube show hosted by Yuri Dud&#39;. Set in St. Petersburg,&nbsp;<em>Tell Her</em>&nbsp;is a young adult drama focusing on a Russian family undergoing a painful divorce.&nbsp;When his mother moves to the United States, 11-year -old Sasha is pulled apart emotionally between two parents, both of whom he loves, and two cultures.&nbsp; Moderated by&nbsp;<a href="https://harriman.columbia.edu/person/mark-lipovetsky/"><strong>Mark Lipovetsky</strong></a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://harriman.columbia.edu/person/tatiana-efremova/"><strong>Tanya Efremova</strong></a>.</p>

summary: Breastfeeding Basics: For Home and Work/School
locationaddress: 516 W. 112 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Workshop,Faculty,Staff,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Postdocs,Graduate Students,Child Care,org/worklife,Wellness,Other
description: <p>This is an educational workshop for expectant and new mothers who want to breastfeed their babies when they return to work or school.&nbsp; Participants will learn breastfeeding basics, including common difficulties and how to manage them, and return-to-work/school strategies and resources.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Presenter: <a href="http://www.heathermcfadden.com/index.html" target="_blank">Heather McFadden</a>&nbsp;is an International Board Certified Lactation Consultant and is currently serving on the board of the New York Lactation Consultant&#39;s Association (<a href="https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=http-3A__www.nylca.org_&amp;d=DwMGaQ&amp;c=009klHSCxuh5AI1vNQzSO0KGjl4nbi2Q0M1QLJX9BeE&amp;r=2K4VbiTCcwYcEyv6bdUXhTdjnps6x1cGFS9xO_jmhvU&amp;m=K--G_LFaDpSie65FyVSRQcxnrw5qbdS7uJML2ge_dR7OTI9W2yK3N2ofoRthDiy_&amp;s=OcRE1EbXD5FqiQZQqoYoJefRSwrUh4G9yIVkfy1BGRE&amp;e=" target="_blank">NYLCA</a>). &nbsp;Heather maintains a private practice offering home visits postpartum as well as prenatal breastfeeding classes and is also a member of the lactation staff at NYU Langone hospital.</p>

summary: Supporting Your Team: Well-Being Strategies for Managers
locationaddress: Online
categories: Type,Location,Audience,Category,Workshop,Online,Staff,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Human Resources,WorkLife,org/worklife,Wellness,Other
description: <p>As leaders, you can have a direct impact on the well-being of your team. By leading with compassion and thoughtfulness, you may help your team better manage daily stressors, juggle multiple responsibilities, prevent burnout, and ultimately create a more positive environment for all. Join us in a conversation with experts from CopeColumbia and the Office of Work/Life as we discuss psychological, well-being, and work/life strategies to sustain the well-being of yourself and your team.</p>

description: <p>** This workshop will be held on Zoom. Links will be provided to registrants before the event. ** Come learn the basics of shell script programming in the Linux operating system as a prelude to learning how to use the High Performance Computing (HPC) resources at Columbia. This is the second in a series of workshops presented by Research Computing Services about using HPC to enhance your research.</p>

summary: Yoga Class
locationaddress: Earl Hall, 2980 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
categories: org/RegLife,Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Sports,Student,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,org/universitylife,Graduate Students,Wellness,Religion,Other
description: <p>Take a break to relax and refresh with yoga in Earl Hall. Free Yoga classes (open level) will be offered in the Auditorium in Earl Hall every&nbsp;Thursday evening&nbsp;during the fall 2022 semester.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>No pre-registration required;&nbsp;open to all Columbia University students. Please bring your own mat and arrive 5-10 minutes early to sign in and set up.&nbsp;There is a 5 minute late policy, doors close at 7:05pm.</p>

summary: Composer Portraits: Luca Francesconi
locationaddress: Miller Theatre, 2960 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
categories: org/neighbors,Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Music,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/Miller,org/UniversityEvents,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Miller Theatre,Graduate Students,Trainees,Concert,Arts
description: <p>The adventurous Ensemble Signal returns to perform two important premieres by Italian composer Luca Francesconi, whose &ldquo;music is the result of a fearless creative voraciousness&rdquo;&nbsp;<em>(The Guardian).</em>&nbsp;His Portrait&mdash;long overdue from two separate postponements over the course of the pandemic&mdash;features a pair of works, including&nbsp;<em>Trauma &Eacute;</em><em>tudes</em>&mdash;a large-scale, powerful piece that reflects on the human experience of trauma in a modern world.</p>

summary: Ask the Experts: Manager Support for the New Work Environment
locationaddress: Online
categories: Type,Location,Audience,Category,Workshop,Online,Staff,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Human Resources,WorkLife,org/worklife,Other
description: <p>Come with your questions! Over the past two years we&rsquo;ve experienced a lot of changes in the way we work and manage our teams. Many questions have emerged from setting schedules, to facilitating hybrid meetings, to best uses of time on-campus. Join all or one of these sessions to engage in Q&amp;A on flexibility, hybrid work, and the new work environment. Share your best practices and learn from other managers across schools and departments. These sessions will be facilitated by representatives from the Office of Work/Life and Human Resources</p>

summary: MPA-Economic Policy Management Virtual Information Session
locationaddress: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: International and Public Affairs,Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Information Session,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,org/sipa,Prospective Students,org/SIPA_PEPM
description: <p>The MPA in Economic Policy Management&nbsp;(<em>formerly PEPM</em>) is designed to provide professionals and policymakers of demonstrated achievement and superior promise with the skills required to design and implement economic policy effectively, with a strong emphasis on the policy issues of developing and transition economies. The Program was initiated as a cooperative endeavor of Columbia University&#39;s School of International and Public Affairs, Graduate School of Business, and Department of Economics in cooperation with the World Bank, and continues to maintain strong ties to the World Bank. &nbsp;Its position, at the heart of Columbia, offers students an Ivy League education at one of the top universities in the world, with access to courses and events featuring world-renowned experts in their fields. &nbsp;</p>\n<p>During this session, David Caughlin, Associate Director of the MPA in Economic Policy Management, will discuss the program&#39;s format, curriculum, outcomes, and resources with time for Q&amp;A at the end.</p>\n<p>Register <a href="https://www.sipa.columbia.edu/academics/degree-programs/mpa-economic-policy-management/register-mpa-epm-information-sessions" target="_blank">here</a></p>

summary: Anti-Racism Speaker Series featuring Dr. Beverly Malone
locationaddress: Online Event
categories: org/EmergencyMedicine,org/SONalumni,org/ethics,org/CRPC,org/lawhr,org/AAADS,org/nursing,org/neighbors,org/NursingAdmissions,org/CSLC,org/NeuroDiversity,org/DEIR,org/CND,org/CUIMChr,org/Anesthesiology,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Online,Lecture,Public,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Social Justice,org/universitylife,Research,org/irvinginstitute,Columbia Nursing,org/cumc_hiccc,org/CUMCGovComAff,org/pathology,org/provost,org/cumc
description: <h1><strong>Register&nbsp;now via <a href="https://columbiacuimc.zoom.us/meeting/register/tJcrdOGupz4uHdNccvckSRxU3C86ybVQCB3L" target="_blank">Zoom</a>.</strong></h1>\n<p>This event will feature Dr. Beverly Malone. Her lecture titled &quot;Courageous Conversations with Self and the Other&quot;&nbsp;will be held virtually on November 10th, 2022.</p>\n<p>Malone has advanced the science of nursing education by promoting greater collaboration among stakeholders, increasing diversity in nursing and nursing education, and advancing excellence in care for patients. Dr. Malone&rsquo;s distinguished career has mixed policy, education, administration, and clinical practice, including as federal deputy assistant secretary for health under President Bill Clinton. Additionally, she has served on many committees, such as the Minority Health Federal Advisory Committee.&nbsp; In 2022, Dr. Malone was honored by the American Nurses Association with the prestigious President&#39;s Award. Dr. Malone was also named one of the 50 Most Influential Clinical Executives by Modern Healthcare.</p>

summary: Microteaching Practice (for Graduate Students)
locationaddress: Butler Library, 535 W. 114 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,org/centertla,Postdocs,Teaching and Learning,Professional Development,Graduate Students
description: <p>Want to practice a new in-class activity or just get some more practice before teaching in your classroom? Join peers in a&nbsp;Microteaching Practice session where you will divide into groups of 3-4 with a facilitator and take turns delivering short samples of instruction to each other. After each teaching sample, your facilitator and your peers will offer structured feedback to support your teaching. Whether you are currently teaching at Columbia or not, all graduate students looking to practice teaching are welcome to attend this Microteaching Practice session. Columbia University makes every effort to accommodate individuals with disabilities.<br />\n<br />\nContact&nbsp;ColumbiaCTL@columbia.edu&nbsp;or 212.854.1692 for accommodations. This event may be photographed. For concerns, contact&nbsp;ColumbiaCTL@columbia.edu.</p>

summary: Gene Editing: Ethical and Social Implications
locationaddress: NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, 622 W. 168 St., New York, NY 10032
categories: org/ethics,Medical Center,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Lecture,Student,Faculty,Staff,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Basic Health Sciences,Clinical Health Sciences,Social Justice,Research,Postdocs,org/irvinginstitute,Healthcare,Graduate Students,College of Physicians and Surgeons,Mailman School of Public Health,Trainees,org/cumc
description: <p>Kelly Ormond, MS, CGC., will give a presentation entitled: &quot;Gene Editing: Ethical and Social Implications in&nbsp;Clinical Application&quot; on Friday,&nbsp;November 11th, 2022 at 10:00-11:00AM ET. The talk will be hosted in the Irving Institute Conference Room (PH-10-204) in the New York Presbyterian Hospital.</p>\n<p>Kelly Ormond is a genetic counselor (US ABGC certified) and ELSI researcher. She received her MS in Genetic Counseling from Northwestern University (1994) and a post-graduate certificate in Clinical Medical Ethics from the MacLean Center at the University of Chicago (2001). She joined the Health Ethics and Policy Lab as a Senior Scientist in February 2021, and maintains a part time position as Clinical Professor in the Department of Genetics at Stanford School of Medicine, Stanford University, California, USA. Prior to joining ETH, Kelly practiced as a clinical genetic counselor in the United States for over 25 years, gaining experience in reproductive genetics, teratology, pediatric/medical genetics, adult neurogenetics, cancer genetics and primary care applications of genetic testing.</p>\n<p>This is an in-person event.&nbsp;Please adhere to Columbia University&#39;s mask policy when attending.</p>

summary: SIT Study Abroad Pre-Departure / Info Session
locationaddress: Kent Hall, 1140 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY 10027
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Student,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Columbia College,Columbia Engineering,First-years,Sophomores,Juniors,Seniors,Global Programs,General Studies,org/OGPF,Study Abroad,Other
description: Join UGE and program representatives from SIT Study Abroad in 606 Kent Hall as we prepare for your semester abroad! Discuss the next steps in the process and what to expect while abroad! There will also be the opportunity for prospective students to learn about SIT since it is not your ordinary study abroad experience. Participate in an academically rigorous, immersive, and field-based study abroad program in Africa, Asia and the Pacific, Europe, Latin America, and the Middle East. Focus on critical global issues or a field of study that will help you discover your academic pursuits, career aspirations, and personal goals. Join us to learn more!

summary: ISSO Newly Arrived J-1 Faculty and Researchers Orientation
locationaddress: Online Event
categories: Type,Location,Audience,Category,Online,Webcast,Information Session,Faculty,Staff,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Postdocs,Orientation,org/ISSO,Trainees,org/cumc,Other
description: <p>This ISSO sponsored event is for Newly Arrived J-1 Faculty and Researchers at Columbia University.<br />\n<br />\nYou are invited to our Newly Arrived J-1 Faculty and Researchers Orientation. These sessions are for those who have recently arrived. The orientation covers an overview of this visa status. ISSO strongly recommends you attend. Please have your DS-2019 and passport available. <a href="https://columbiauniversity.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_Ea07neYRS0Si4G5R4kLPKg" target="_blank">Register here</a>.</p>

summary: Ask the Ergonomist: An Introduction to Working Comfortably
locationaddress: Online
categories: Type,Location,Audience,Category,Workshop,Online,Faculty,Staff,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Postdocs,org/worklife,Wellness,Other
description: <p>Create a workspace that is comfortable, supportive, and personalized to you! Join us for an introductory ergonomics session, where you will learn the foundations of ergonomics, find out how to cultivate a healthier workspace, and participate in extended Q&amp;A with the university&rsquo;s ergonomist. Leave this session with practical tips, personalized ergonomic adjustments, new habits, and strategies to work and feel better.</p>\n<p><strong>Instructor: </strong>Kevin Myers, MS, AEP, ATC, CLC is the University&rsquo;s Ergonomist who holds a Master of Science in Ergonomics and Biomechanics from New York University, a license as a Certified Athletic Trainer, and certification as a Certified Life Coach.</p>\n<p><a href="https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/RXGYKPH" target="_blank"><strong>REGISTER</strong></a></p>

summary: Lights on the Plaza
locationaddress: Lenfest Center for the Arts, 615 W. 129 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: org/neighbors,org/forum,Manhattanville,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Reception,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Ceremony,Graduate Students,Trainees,Community,Other
description: <p>Join us on &ldquo;The Plaza&rdquo; for Columbia University&rsquo;s annual Manhattanville winter tree lighting ceremony. We&#39;ll begin the lights countdown promptly at 5:30 PM.&nbsp;Refreshments will be provided. Festive dress optional, but encouraged.</p>\n<p>The tree lighting will take place prior to the&nbsp;<a href="https://harlembid.com/harlem-light-it-up/" target="_blank">125th Street Business Improvement District&#39;s annual Harlem Holiday Lights parade</a>, which will begin at 6 PM on Tuesday, on the corner of 125th St. and Broadway.</p>\n<p>Come join the festivities with your neighbors! Please RSVP below.&nbsp;</p>

summary: Michelangelo’s “David” and his Sling: A Talk by Luca Giuliani
locationaddress: Italian Academy, 1161 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY 10027
categories: org/italianacademy,Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Lecture,Public,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Other
description: <p><strong><em>What does the sling mean for our understanding of the work?</em></strong></p>\n<p>One of the great Greek and Roman archaeologists of our time, Luca Giuliani (Italian Academy Fellow 2022) also trained in social anthropology and Italian literature. He was a curator in the Antikenmuseum in West Berlin; he taught at the University of Freiburg and at the Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich; and he served as Rector of the Institute of Advanced Study (Wissenschaftskolleg) in Berlin, where he still holds the position of Permanent Fellow.</p>

summary: Film Screening & Discussion. "Core of the World"
locationaddress: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Film,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Trainees,Russia,org/SIPA_HarrimanInstitute,Humanities
description: <h2>Important Note</h2>\n<p><strong>Registration required. Please note that all attendees must follow Columbia&rsquo;s&nbsp;<a href="https://covid19.columbia.edu/" target="_blank">COVID-19 Policies and Guidelines</a>. Columbia University is committed to protecting the health and safety of its community.&nbsp; To that end,&nbsp;<strong>all visiting alumni and guests</strong>&nbsp;must meet the University requirement of full vaccination status in order to attend in-person events.&nbsp; Vaccination cards may be checked upon entry to all venues.&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong></p>\n<p>Please join us for a screening of&nbsp;<em>Core of the World&nbsp;</em>(2018) by&nbsp;<strong>Natalia Meschaninova</strong>, the second film in the Fall 2022 Harriman Film Series&nbsp;<em>Warning Signs.</em>&nbsp;In the remote Russian countryside, Egor works as a veterinarian at a training center for hunting dogs. Raised and then abandoned by his alcoholic mother, he explores the need for belonging and acceptance. Struggling to escape from the troubled past, Egor feels safer among animals than humans. When he is brought a wounded dog by his boss, Egor commits to curing her, despite his boss&rsquo;s objections. A Russian-Lithuanian co-production,&nbsp;<em>Core of the World&nbsp;</em>(2018) was well-received at international film festivals and awarded a Grand Prix at Kinotavr. Moderated by&nbsp;<strong><a href="https://harriman.columbia.edu/person/mark-lipovetsky/">Mark Lipovetsky</a></strong>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<strong><a href="https://harriman.columbia.edu/person/tatiana-efremova/">Tanya Efremova</a></strong>.</p>

summary: Cut the Clutter and Get Organized (in-person)
locationaddress: Hybrid Event
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Workshop,Faculty,Staff,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Postdocs,Graduate Students,Housing,WorkLife,org/worklife
description: <p>Need some tips on how to better organize your home or office&mdash;or your office at home&mdash;and spend less time looking for your things? Three professional organizers will provide you with valuable techniques for de-cluttering and suggest tools to help you stay organized. Attend with your questions in order to receive specific guidance.</p>\n<p>Wendy Samuel, Clutter Therapy, LLC; Gail Furgal, Outtasight Organizing, LLC; and Donna Goldberg, The Organized Student, LLC</p>

summary: MGG/SGT Seminar
locationaddress: Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, 61 Route 9W, Palisades, NY 10964
categories: org/CCS,org/MGG,Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Seminar,Student,Faculty,Staff,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Trainees,org/LDEO,Natural Sciences
description: <p><strong>Speaker:&nbsp;</strong>Higgins Professor Emeritus Lynn Sykes (LDEO)</p>\n<p><strong>Title:</strong>&nbsp;Intermediate and Long Term Forerunners to Major Earthquakes</p>
xproperties: X-BEDEWORK-REGISTRATION-GUEST-ACCESS : values : text : 	email,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-MGG/Location/Lamont-Doherty,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-MGG/Type/Seminar,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-MGG/Events open to/Faculty,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-MGG/Events open to/Graduate Students,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-MGG/Events open to/Postdocs,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-MGG/Events open to/Prospective Students,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-MGG/Events open to/Staff,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-MGG/Events open to/Student,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-MGG/Events open to/Trainees,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-MGG/Category/Natural Sciences,X-BEDEWORK-SHORTTITLE : values : text : MGG/SGT Seminar,X-BEDEWORK-SUBMITTEDBY : values : text : ajl2283 for MGG and SGT Seminars (agrp_MGG),X-BEDEWORK-DESCRIPTION-FORMAT : values : text : html,X-BEDEWORK-CALSUITE : values : text : MGG and SGT Seminars,X-BEDEWORK-ADDITIONAL-INFO : values : text : Abstract: For the past few decades I have worked on identifying seismic gaps along active plate boundaries, i.e., places that have not ruptured for a long time in great earthquakes and studied repeat times of great shocks. I am now working to learn more about forerunning effects on time scales of decades to months including changes in seismic activity. My talk emphasizes them. As a scientific community, we are far from being able to predict earthquakes on various time scales. My aim is to be able to forecast a few shocks, not all large events. Many U.S. seismologists think earthquake prediction is for “fools and charlatans.” The U.S. earth science community has not taken such extreme views since their rejection of continental drift in the half century up until 1966.

summary: CU Safe Zone Training Workshop
locationaddress: Lerner Hall, 2920 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
categories: org/RegLife,org/CCS,Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Workshop,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Social Justice,org/universitylife,Postdocs,Columbia College,Columbia Engineering,Mentoring,First-years,Sophomores,Juniors,Seniors,First-Generation Students,Transfer Students,Exchange Students,Visiting Students,Countdown to Columbia,Prospective Students,org/ColumbiaHealth,Professional Development,Graduate Students,General Studies,Trainees,org/UndergradStudentLife,Study Break,Faculty in Residence,Leadership,West Campus,Alternative Break Program,Civic Engagement,Respecting Ourselves and Others Through Education (ROOTEd),Undergraduate Student Life,Multicultural Affairs,Residential Life,Student Engagement,International @ Columbia,LGBTQ @ Columbia,First Generation @ Columbia,Fraternity and Sorority Life,Residence Hall Leadership Organization (RHLO),Special Interest Communities,Global Ambassador Program,Men of Color Alliance,Live at Lerner,Urban NY,First Year Area,E-block
description: <p>CU Safe Zone is a training session that provides the foundational knowledge needed to support and act in solidarity with LGBTQ+ communities at Columbia University. Offered by Multicultural Affairs, this campus-wide program was designed to educate and visibly identify students, faculty and staff who support the LGBTQ+ community; provide an overview of LGBTQ+ communities and some of the issues these communities face; and share various LGBTQ resources available to folks on campus.</p>\n<p><a href="https://www.cc-seas.columbia.edu/InclusionSeries" target="_blank">Registration is Required</a></p>

summary: HICCC Exceptional Scholar Seminar
locationaddress: Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center, 1130 St. Nicholas Ave., New York, NY 10032
categories: Medical Center,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Seminar,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Basic Health Sciences,Clinical Health Sciences,Research,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Healthcare,Graduate Students,College of Physicians and Surgeons,Trainees,org/cumc_hiccc,org/cumc
description: <p>Curtis Henry, PhD, Assistant Professor in the Department of Pediatrics at Emory University School of Medicine; Member, Cancer Immunology Research Program at Winship Cancer Institute.</p>\n<p>Dr. Henry&#39;s research seeks to determine how chronic inflammation shapes hematopoiesis, immunity, and leukemogenesis. Results from these studies will be applied to improving therapeutic responses in at risk populations including children who are overweight or obese and aged populations.</p>

summary: Fast Pitch 2022 Competition ~ Calling all Entrepreneurs!
locationaddress: Schapiro CEPSR, 530 W. 120 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: org/SEAS_Entrepreneurship,International and Public Affairs,Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Seminar,Reception,Business,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Computer Science,Postdocs,Global Programs,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Trainees,Community,Communications / Media,Engineering
description: <p>We&#39;re starting competition season again with <strong>Fast Pitch</strong> on November 16. Watch the competitors pitch their ideas in 60 seconds in front of a live panel of judges to win up to $5,000. Fast and furious, Fast Pitch is Columbia&#39;s elevator pitch competition. Winning teams will be judged to be the most concise, complete, and compelling. Attendance is free, the experience is priceless. If you&#39;d like to watch, and possibly find a founder, co-founder, or team member, register for the event! Undergrad and grad students from all schools and institutes across Columbia University are eligible to participate. <a href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/columbia-fast-pitch-competition-2022-registration-441590819027" target="_blank">RSVP for the event</a></p>

summary: Our Apocalypses
locationaddress: Buell Hall, 515 W. 116 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Lecture,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,org/icls,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,org/maison,Graduate School of Arts and Sciences,Trainees,Humanities,Religion
description: <p><strong>RSVP&nbsp;<a href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/our-apocalypses-tickets-449505532147">HERE</a></strong></p>\n<p>In her recently published book,&nbsp;<em>Nos Apocalypses</em>, a finalist for the 2022 Prix Medicis, Clemence Boulouque unveils an overview of religious responses to epidemics, from Exodus to the coronavirus, and of literary description of diseases,&nbsp;from Boccacio and Goethe, to Camus and Octavia Butler. Both scriptures and literary texts function as vehicles of social criticism. They allow us to engage with questions of collective guilt, collective mourning, divine justice (or lack thereof), and grapple with the societal disruptions,&nbsp;persecution and discriminations&nbsp;that illnesses create or expose. While some of the parallels with our current times are obvious, these texts also help us nuance the responses to past&nbsp;epidemics, and read them anew.&nbsp;<em>Nos Apocalypses&nbsp;</em>is also an invitation to read scriptures as literature and to ponder the uses of religious imagination in order to come up with new ways of imagining what&nbsp;brings us together when disaster befalls us. &nbsp;</p>\n<p><strong>Cl&eacute;mence Boulouque</strong>&nbsp;is the Carl and Bernice Witten Associate Professor in Jewish and Israel studies at Columbia University. &nbsp;She is the author of&nbsp;<em>Another Modernity: Elia Benamozegh&#39;s Jewish Universalism</em>&nbsp;(Stanford University Press) and co-editor of the Stanford Studies in Jewish Mysticism series.&nbsp;Her interests include Jewish thought and mysticism, interreligious encounters, intellectual history and networks with a focus on the modern Mediterranean and Sefardi worlds, as well as the intersection between religion and the arts, and the study of the unconscious. Prior to embarking on an academic career, Cl&eacute;mence Boulouque worked as a novelist and literary and movie critic in Paris. &nbsp;</p>

summary: M.S in Sustainability Management Online Information Session
locationaddress: Online Event
categories: org/CCS,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Online,Information Session,Business,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Earth Institute,Postdocs,Admissions,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Trainees,org/OARP
description: <h3><a href="https://apply.sps.columbia.edu/register/?id=a3fb20f7-c990-4582-b90f-a2389330dad0" target="_blank"><strong>Please&nbsp;RSVP&nbsp;here</strong></a></h3>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Please join us for an online information session on the <a href="https://www.sustainability.ei.columbia.edu/" target="_blank">MS in Sustainability Managemen</a>t program, offered jointly by Columbia Climate School&#39;s&nbsp;Earth Institute and School of Professional Studies&nbsp;at Columbia University.&nbsp;his program is designed for those who wish to pursue a career in management that takes into account both the environment and the economy. Graduates transform how organizations do business by formulating and implementing sustainability strategies. The coursework combines the study of management with classes in state-of-the-art sustainability practice and science, with full-time and part-time options for those with current professional obligations.</p>

summary: MPA-Economic Policy Management Virtual Information Session
locationaddress: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: International and Public Affairs,Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Information Session,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,org/sipa,Prospective Students,org/SIPA_PEPM
description: <p>The MPA in Economic Policy Management&nbsp;(<em>formerly PEPM</em>) is designed to provide professionals and policymakers of demonstrated achievement and superior promise with the skills required to design and implement economic policy effectively, with a strong emphasis on the policy issues of developing and transition economies. The Program was initiated as a cooperative endeavor of Columbia University&#39;s School of International and Public Affairs, Graduate School of Business, and Department of Economics in cooperation with the World Bank, and continues to maintain strong ties to the World Bank. &nbsp;Its position, at the heart of Columbia, offers students an Ivy League education at one of the top universities in the world, with access to courses and events featuring world-renowned experts in their fields. &nbsp;</p>\n<p>During this session, David Caughlin, Associate Director of the MPA in Economic Policy Management, will discuss the program&#39;s format, curriculum, outcomes, and resources with time for Q&amp;A at the end.</p>\n<p>Register <a href="https://www.sipa.columbia.edu/academics/degree-programs/mpa-economic-policy-management/register-mpa-epm-information-sessions" target="_blank">here</a></p>

summary: Monthly overview of IRI's Global Seasonal Climate Forecasts and ENSO status and forecast.
locationaddress: Online

description: The International Research Institute for Climate and Society (IRI) presents its climate forecast briefing. The IRI's seasonal, sub-seasonal and ENSO (El Niño Southern Oscillation) forecasts are discussed in this monthly briefing by IRI climate scientists Azhar Ehsan and Bohar Singh.\nFor more information, please see: https://iri.columbia.edu/our-expertise/climate/

locationaddress: Lenfest Center for the Arts, 615 W. 129 St., New York, NY 10027
contactname: Columbia University School of the Arts
categories: Manhattanville,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Lecture,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,org/ilas,org/soa,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Trainees,Arts
description: <p>Celebrated visual artist <strong>Tania Bruguera</strong> presents work in conjunction with the exhibition <a href="https://wallach.columbia.edu/exhibitions/sin-autorizaci%C3%B3n-contemporary-cuban-art" target="_blank"><em>Sin Autorizaci&oacute;n: Contemporary Cuban Art</em></a>. Introduced by <strong>Betti-Sue Hertz</strong>, Director and Chief Curator, Miriam and Ira D. Wallach Art Gallery.</p>\n<p><strong><a href="https://www.lenfest.arts.columbia.edu/fall-2022-events/tania-bruguera" target="_blank">Register online.</a></strong></p>\n<p>Co-presented by the Institute for Latin American Studies; the Miriam and Ira D. Wallach Art Gallery; and the School of the Arts Visual Arts Program.</p>

locationaddress: Earl Hall, 2980 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
categories: org/RegLife,Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Sports,Student,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,org/universitylife,Graduate Students,Wellness,Religion,Other
description: <p>Take a break to relax and refresh with yoga in Earl Hall. Free Yoga classes (open level) will be offered in the Auditorium in Earl Hall every&nbsp;Thursday evening&nbsp;during the fall 2022 semester.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>No pre-registration required;&nbsp;open to all Columbia University students. Please bring your own mat and arrive 5-10 minutes early to sign in and set up.&nbsp;There is a 5 minute late policy, doors close at 7:05pm.</p>

summary: Meet UGE's Global Learning Ambassadors | IEW
locationaddress: College Walk, Columbia University, 116th St. Between Broadway & Amsterdam, New York, NY 10027
categories: Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Student,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Columbia College,Columbia Engineering,First-years,Sophomores,Juniors,Seniors,Global Programs,General Studies,org/gs,org/OGPF,Study Abroad,Other
description: Chat with the Center for Undergraduate Global Engagement's Global Learning Ambassadors on College Walk to take your goals global! Global Learning Ambassadors (GLAs) are student leaders on campus supporting the conversation around global engagement. Whether they are sharing their former study abroad experience or facilitating dialogues around globally-minded topics, they are eager to talk with you about what programs we offer and the general study abroad process! Snacks will be available, so stop by between 11:00 AM - 1:00 PM to meet these incredible GLAs!

description: <p>Columbia Health Counseling and Psychological Services is&nbsp;hosting a ONE TIME&nbsp;<a href="https://nam02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.health.columbia.edu%2Fcontent%2Fsupport-groups%23!%23cu_accordion_item-9386&amp;data=05%7C01%7Cgmg2171%40cumc.columbia.edu%7C72a377e3657c4c47312b08dac26e6b0d%7Cb0002a9b0017404d97dc3d3bab09be81%7C0%7C0%7C638036076735182618%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&amp;sdata=qMiREg8%2FpySKWK7Sw%2BMy%2FhiNIDzRT3klUUB6cCDxdlo%3D&amp;reserved=0" target="_blank">support space for Korean students impacted by the Halloween tragedy at Itaewon</a>, facilitated by&nbsp;Drs. Deborah Ohm and Arthur Roh.</p>\n<p>The virtual support space will be held on&nbsp;<strong>Friday, 11/18 from 12 - 1 PM&nbsp;</strong>on&nbsp;<strong>Zoom</strong>.&nbsp;Students may speak openly in a safe environment, to feel a sense of connection and community, and to learn about available resources at Columbia.</p>\n<p>To register, email do2415@cumc.columbia.edu or ar3068@cumc.columbia.edu with &quot;Korean Support Space&quot; in the subject line.</p>

summary: Russia's Federalist Imagination
locationaddress: International Affairs Building, 420 W. 118 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: International and Public Affairs,Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Lecture,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Trainees,East Central Europe,org/SIPA_HarrimanInstitute
description: <p><strong>Registration required. Please note that all attendees must follow Columbia&rsquo;s&nbsp;<a href="https://covid19.columbia.edu/" target="_blank">COVID-19 Policies and Guidelines</a>. Columbia University is committed to protecting the health and safety of its community.&nbsp; To that end,&nbsp;<strong>all visiting alumni and guests</strong>&nbsp;must meet the University requirement of full vaccination status in order to attend in-person events.&nbsp; Vaccination cards may be checked upon entry to all venues.&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong></p>\n<p>Please join the East Central European Center and the Harriman Institute for a discussion with&nbsp;<a href="https://harriman.columbia.edu/person/marcel-garbos/" target="_blank"><strong>Marcel Garbo</strong></a>, Istv&aacute;n Deak Visiting Professor of East Central European Studies.</p>\n<p>In the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, the Russian empire and its international emigre colonies emerged as a vibrant laboratory of federalist thought and politics. While the multinational Soviet Union was the best-known and most internationally influential product of this milieu, the Bolsheviks were relative latecomers to federalism, drawing upon the established ideas of more moderate and generally overlooked socialist competitors. This presentation offers a glimpse into the international circulation of federal frameworks between late imperial Russia and the wider world, highlighting abortive yet ambitious attempts at incorporating models from Anglophone and German-speaking countries into projects of post-Tsarist order. Following the ideas and travels of Russian-, Ukrainian-, and Polish-speaking socialists, it locates this rich federalist imagination within pan-European and global contexts often elided in conventional Soviet-oriented narratives.</p>

summary: Library Q&A for FGLI Students
locationaddress: Butler Library, 535 W. 114 St., New York, NY 10027

description: <p>The Columbia University and Barnard College libraries invite you to join an open conversation about library support for FGLI students. Learn more about academic libraries, access to course materials, and other sources/support available to you. Ask questions and make suggestions about the libraries in a judgement-free environment. Discover more about the history, present, and future of the FLI Partnership lending libraries at both Columbia and Barnard. We look forward to speaking with you.</p>

summary: A talk with Juan González, an award-winning Journalist & Reporter
locationaddress: Pulitzer Hall, 2950 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
categories: org/CSER,Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Social Sciences,Panel,Social Justice,Postdocs,Government and Public Policy,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Graduate School of Arts and Sciences,Trainees,Communications / Media,Journalism,Humanities,Other
description: <p>Please join Nina Alvarez (Columbia School of Journalism), Claudio Lomnitz (Anthropology &amp; CSER), and Ed Morales (CSER) for&nbsp;a discussion with Juan D. Gonz&aacute;lez, one of the founders and leaders of the Young Lords Party, and current Richard D. Hefner Professor of Comunications and Public Policy at Rutgers University on his time before and after his career in journalism.&nbsp;</p>

summary: Orlando Consort - 1521: Josquin's World
locationaddress: Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 145 W. 46 St., New York, NY 10036
categories: org/neighbors,Off Campus,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Music,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/Miller,org/UniversityEvents,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Miller Theatre,Graduate Students,Trainees,Concert,Arts
description: <p>The brilliant Orlando Consort marks the end of an era with their final season together. For their&nbsp;farewell&nbsp;program, they reflect on Josquin Desprez, the greatest and most influential composer the western world had yet seen at&nbsp;the time of his&nbsp;death,&nbsp;500 years ago. Experience a magical sequence of music that reflects on the composer and his world. And don&#39;t miss your last chance to hear one of the most joyous and legendary vocal&nbsp;ensembles of our time.</p>

summary: Winter Clothing Drive
locationaddress: Lerner Hall, 2920 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
categories: org/RegLife,org/neighbors,Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,org/universitylife,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Graduate Students,Trainees,Community,Other
description: <p>Please bring any winter clothing donations (jackets, hats, gloves, scarves, sweater, cardigans) to the Lerner Ramp on Monday, November 21st from 10:30 AM - 1:30 PM.&nbsp;Professional clothing also appreciated!&nbsp;Donations will be distributed&nbsp;to&nbsp;clients at the&nbsp;<a href="https://www.communityimpact.columbia.edu/content/food-pantry" target="_blank">Food Pantry at Ford Hall</a>.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>This event is hosted by&nbsp;<a href="https://www.communityimpact.columbia.edu/" target="_blank">Community Impact</a>.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>
